page.title: 19Brockhampton Manor(History)
page.content: Within the chief manor,which has been attached to the See of Hereford from a period before the Domesday Survey, a number of less important manors are included.Of these one of the most important is Brockhampton which lies in the town ship of Norton and gave its name to a family seated there early in the thirteenth century. Richard son of Robert de Brockhampton sold his lands and the advowson of the chapel to Robert de Furches circa 1203. Soon afterwards they were in the possession of the Solers family and by about the middle of the fourteenth century were held by Sir Thomas le Moigne,hence they probably passed to the Rowdons but there is no proof.The Domultons were the next proprietors succeeded by the Habingtons.At the death of JR.Habington,the elder daughter married Richard Barneby.
